the game has to know what to do with
content. Like that's the most important

good and data driven. So you can't do a

that stuff to be available to mod
creators, you need to have nice good
blueprint hooks and things like that.

data asset you use that's going to

range of custom applications. So, like
for instance, if someone wants to make a

you need to make sure that whatever it

Um, so then when you're designing your
systems with mod support in mind, uh,
you want to maintain decent blue
blueprint hierarchies and know which
content is going to be provided to the
mod creator. Uh, this perfect example is
if you have like licensed content or
something like that. Obviously, you
don't want that to end up in uh, some
sort of creation kit for your players,
but you need to have base classes so
that they have support for almost any
sort of thing they might do. For
instance, if you were making a new
weapon or if you wanted them to make a
new weapon, uh you'd want to put all the
functionality for a pistol in some sort
of base pistol class, but you not might
not want to provide the actual pistol
content to them. So, make sure that
there's a good hierarchy of how to make
that sort of functionality available to
them. Uh the more datadriven things are,
the easier it is to integrate mods. I
think that goes without saying. Um use
blueprint hooks. And so what I mean by
this is if you've been making functions
blueprint uh callable a lot, maybe make
them blueprint native events, if you
think it might be something someone
might want to override, this does have
some overhead. Uh so like if you make
something blueprint callable when you do
a C++ to C++ call, that's pretty much
instantaneous. Um however, once you make
it a blueprint native event, uh then
it's got to have to check an actual
function map on the class to to do the
call. Uh so that does slow things down.
So don't do this on something that's in
any core loops or anything like that.
Um, and then add hooks for things you
don't use. Uh, so I put an example of on
weapon attached. Maybe you don't need
that in your class, but if you have
things like that for like on possess, on
weapon attached, when game mode events
happen, things like that that are have
blueprint extensible events, then the
players can go in and make cool changes
or make new things that you wouldn't
even think of.
